Meaning: Amounts that a company owes to suppliers or vendors for goods and services received but not yet paid for
Amounts that a company is owed by its customers for goods or services that have been sold but not yet paid for
The total amount of depreciation that has been charged to a company's assets over their useful life
The amount of capital that has been invested by shareholders in excess of the par value of the company's shares
An estimated amount of potential bad debts that a company expects will not be collected from its customers
Lease obligations that are considered to be similar to debt because the lessee has assumed the risks and rewards of ownership of the leased asset
The total amount of shares that a company is authorized to issue
The total amount of cash held by a company, including cash on hand and in bank accounts, as well as highly liquid investments that can be quickly converted into cash
The total amount of cash, cash equivalents and highly liquid investments that can be easily converted into cash held by a company
Cash and cash equivalents that are held for the purpose of meeting short-term financial obligations
Shares of a company that represent ownership in the company and carry voting rights
The total amount of equity that is represented by the common stock of a company
Expenses that have been incurred but have not yet been paid
Assets that are expected to be converted into cash within one year
The portion of capital lease obligations that is due within the next 12 months
Debt that is due within the next 12 months
The total amount of debt and capital lease obligations that is due within the next 12 months
Liabilities that have been recognized but will not be paid until a future period
Revenue that has been recognized but will not be earned until a future period
Liabilities that are due within one year
Short-term notes that are due within the next 12 months
Amounts that a company has set aside to cover expected future expenses or losses
Liabilities that arise from the use of derivative financial instruments
Assets that have a financial value and can be traded, such as stocks, bonds, and options
Products that have been completed and are ready to be sold
Gains or losses that are not included in the calculation of retained earnings, such as gains or losses on the sale of investments
The excess of the purchase price of an acquired company over the fair value of its net assets
The total amount of goodwill and other intangible assets held by a company
The total amount of accounts receivable before any allowances for doubtful accounts have been made
The total cost of a company's property, plant, and equipment before any accumulated depreciation has been deducted
Assets that are used to hedge against potential losses from changes in market conditions
The amount of income tax that a company owes to the government
The amount of interest that a company owes to its lenders
Goods that a company holds for sale to customers
Total amount of capital that has been invested in a company's operations, including equity and debt
Properties that a company holds for long-term rental income or for capital appreciation, rather than for use in its own operations
Type of credit facility that allows a borrower to draw funds up to a certain limit as needed, and to repay the borrowed amount at any time. Interest is only paid on the amount borrowed
The portion of a long-term lease obligation that is considered a capital lease. Capital leases are those that transfer ownership of the leased asset to the lessee at the end of the lease term
This is debt that has a maturity of more than one year
Sum of a company's long-term debt and its long-term capital lease obligations
Liabilities that are expected to be paid over a period of more than one year
The fixed assets of a company that are used in its operations, such as machinery, furniture, and equipment
Difference between a company's total debt and its cash and cash equivalents
Net book value of a company's property, plant, and equipment (ppe) after deducting accumulated depreciation
Net book value of a company's tangible assets (assets that have a physical form and can be touched), after deducting accumulated depreciation
Amounts due to a company that are expected to be received more than one year from the balance sheet date
Assets that will be used or consumed after more than one year from the balance sheet date
Liabilities that will not be paid until more than one year from the balance sheet date
Revenue that has been received in advance but will not be recognized as revenue until more than one year from the balance sheet date
The tax assets that will not be realized until more than one year from the balance sheet date
The tax liabilities that will not be paid until more than one year from the balance sheet date
The number of ordinary shares (also known as common shares) that a company has outstanding
Short-term borrowings that are not classified as accounts payable or as part of a long-term debt
Current liabilities that are not classified as accounts payable or as short-term borrowings

Other equity adjustments refer to changes in a company's equity that are not due to transactions with shareholders or dividends. These adjustments can result from changes in accounting standards, foreign currency translation adjustments, or other factors that impact a company's equity
Other intangible assets include any non-physical assets that lack a physical form but still hold value, such as patents, trademarks, copyrights, and goodwill

Other payable is a liability account that includes debts that do not fall under a company's other payable accounts. This account can include items such as deferred payments or payments for non-operating expenses
Other properties refer to any property, plant, or equipment (pp&e) that does not fall under a specific category. This could include buildings or equipment that are unique to the company's operations

Other receivables are a current asset account that includes money owed to the company that does not fall under the company's accounts receivable account. This could include loans made to employees or deposits paid for future services
Amounts owed by a company to suppliers for goods or services purchased on credit

Payables and accrued expenses refer to the total amount of outstanding expenses that a company has incurred but has not yet paid. This account includes both current liabilities and expenses that are not yet due
Pension and other post-retirement benefit plans current refers to the portion of a company's long-term employee benefit plans that are due within the next year

Prepaid assets are current assets that represent payments made by a company for goods or services that have not yet been received. These assets are usually expensed over time as the goods or services are consumed
Properties refer to any physical assets that a company owns, including land, buildings, and equipment
Receivables are current assets that represent money owed to a company by its customers for goods or services provided
Retained earnings are the portion of a company's profits that are reinvested back into the business rather than paid out as dividends to shareholders
Share issued refers to the total number of shares of a company's stock that have been issued and are outstanding

Stockholders equity, also known as shareholder's equity, is the residual value of a company's assets after liabilities have been deducted. It represents the amount of equity that shareholders hold in the company

Tangible book value is a measure of a company's net worth that excludes intangible assets, such as goodwill or patents. It is calculated by subtracting a company's liabilities and intangible assets from its tangible assets
Taxes receivable are current assets that represent taxes owed to a company by a taxing authority that have not yet been paid
Total assets are the sum of a company's current and non-current assets
Total capitalization represents the total amount of debt and equity financing that a company has used to fund its operations
Total debt is the sum of a company's current and long-term debt
Total equity gross minority interest represents the total value of a company's equity, including the value of any minority interests
Total liabilities of a company, including any liabilities related to minority interests in subsidiaries
Total value of a company's non-current (long-term) assets
Total value of a company's non-current (long-term) liabilities, including any liabilities related to minority interests in subsidiaries
The amount of taxes that a company owes to tax authorities
Amounts that a company owes to suppliers and other parties, which are not due for payment within one year
The number of a company's own shares that it has repurchased and is holding in treasury
Shares of a company's own stock that it has repurchased and held in its treasury for future use
The difference between a company's current assets and its current liabilities, representing the amount of capital available for day-to-day operations
The amount of cash outflow due to amortization of intangible assets
The process of spreading out the cost of an intangible asset over its useful life in a systematic and rational manner
A non-cash expense that reflects the reduction in the value of an asset due to an impairment loss
The amount of cash a company has at the beginning of a period
The money a company spends to acquire, upgrade, or maintain long-term assets such as property, plant, and equipment
The total amount of cash paid by a company to its shareholders as dividends
The net amount of cash inflows and outflows from financing activities that are expected to continue in the future
The net amount of cash inflows and outflows from investing activities that are expected to continue in the future
The net amount of cash inflows and outflows from operating activities that are expected to continue in the future
The net increase or decrease in cash and cash equivalents for a given period
The change in the value of a company's inventory during a period
The net change in other current assets and liabilities during a period
The change in the value of a company's payables during a period
The change in the value of a company's payables and accrued expenses during a period
The change in the value of a company's prepaid assets during a period
The change in the value of a company's accounts receivable during a period
The net change in a company's current assets and liabilities during a period
The net change in a company's accounts receivable during a period
The net change in a company's cash and cash equivalents during a period
The amount of dividends paid on common stock during a period
The amount of payments made for the issuance of common stock during a period
The amount of a company's long-term assets that have been used up or consumed during a period
The total amount of depreciation, amortization, and depletion expenses incurred by a company during a period
The total amount of depreciation and amortization expenses incurred by a company during a period
The impact of changes in exchange rates on a company's financial statements during a period
The amount of cash a company has at the end of a period
The net amount of cash inflows and outflows from financing activities during a period
The amount of cash generated by a company after deducting capital expenditures
The gain or loss on the sale or disposition of investment securities during a period
The gain or loss on the sale of property, plant, and equipment during a period
The amount of interest paid by a company on its debt during a period
The amount of interest received by a company during a specific period that is included in its operating cash flow

The cash inflows and outflows resulting from the acquisition or disposal of long-term assets, such as property, plant and equipment, investment properties, and intangible assets. It is one of the three sections of the cash flow statement
The proceeds from the sale of new debt securities, such as bonds or notes, by a company
The amount of long-term debt issued by a company during a specific period
The amount of long-term debt principal and interest paid by a company during a specific period
The difference between the amount of common stock issued and the amount of common stock repurchased by a company during a specific period
The net gain or loss resulting from the translation of foreign currency denominated accounts of a company
The total income earned by a company during a specific period, calculated by subtracting total expenses from total revenues
The portion of a company's net income that is generated from its ongoing business activities, after subtracting any income or losses from discontinued operations or extraordinary items
The net amount of intangible assets acquired or disposed of by a company during a specific period
The net amount of investment properties acquired or disposed of by a company during a specific period
The net amount of investments in securities, such as stocks or bonds, acquired or disposed of by a company during a specific period
The net amount of long-term debt issued or repaid by a company during a specific period
The net amount of long-term debt issued by a company during a specific period
The net amount of property, plant, and equipment acquired or disposed of by a company during a specific period
The cash generated from a company's operating activities, such as sales of goods and services, and is calculated by subtracting operating expenses from operating revenues
The gains or losses resulting from a company's ordinary course of business operations, such as the sale of inventory or the disposal of equipment
The non-cash transactions that do not affect a company's cash position, such as the depreciation of assets, the amortization of intangibles, or the provision for bad debt
The amount of expense recorded by a company for the depreciation of assets, amortization of intangible assets, or the write-off of bad debt
The amount of money spent by a company to acquire intangible assets, such as patents, trademarks, or copyrights
The amount of money spent by a company to acquire investments in securities, such as stocks or bonds
The amount of money spent by a company to acquire investment properties, such as real estate
The amount of money spent by a company to acquire property, plant, and equipment
The amount of long-term debt principal and interest repaid by a company during a specific period
The amount of money spent by a company to buy back its own shares
Revenue generated from the sale of intangible assets, such as patents, copyrights, and trademarks
Revenue generated from the sale of property, plant, and equipment
A method of compensating employees and executives by granting them stock options or shares in the company
Refunds of taxes previously paid by a company to the government
The process of spreading the cost of an intangible asset over its useful life
The portion of the cost of an intangible asset that is expensed on the income statement over its useful life
The weighted average number of shares outstanding during a specific period, used to calculate earnings per share
Earnings per share calculated by dividing a company's net income by its weighted average number of shares outstanding during a specific period
The total amount of depreciation, amortization, and depletion expenses charged against a company's revenues on the income statement
The total amount of depreciation and amortization expenses charged against a company's revenues on the income statement
The portion of the cost of a tangible asset that is expensed on the income statement over its useful life
The weighted average number of shares outstanding during a specific period, adjusted for the potential impact of dilutive securities such as stock options and convertible bonds
Earnings per share calculated by dividing a company's net income by its diluted average shares outstanding during a specific period
Net income available to common stockholders, adjusted for the potential impact of dilutive securities
Earnings before interest and taxes, representing a company's operating profit
Earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization, representing a company's operating cash flow
The profit earned by a company from the sale of property, plant, and equipment
The profit earned by a company from the sale of securities
A category of expenses incurred by a company that are not directly related to the production or sale of its goods or services, including salaries, rent, and office supplies
A reduction in the value of a long-term asset due to damage, obsolescence, or other factors
The cost of borrowing money, including interest payments on loans and bonds
Interest expense that is not directly related to a company's operations, such as interest paid on debt used to finance acquisitions
Revenue generated from interest-bearing assets such as bonds, loans, and savings accounts
Interest income that is not directly related to a company's operations, such as interest earned on investments in other companies
The total income earned by a company during a specific period, calculated by subtracting total expenses from total revenues
A company's net income after deducting any dividends paid to preferred stockholders
A company's net income from its ongoing business activities, excluding any income or losses from discontinued operations
A company's net income from both its ongoing business activities and any income or losses from discontinued operations

Portion of a company's net income that is attributed to the minority shareholders. It represents the income earned by the company's operations after deducting interest, taxes, and other expenses, and is calculated by subtracting the minority interest expense from the net income of continuing operations
Net income of a company that includes both the portion attributable to the company's common shareholders and the portion attributable to the minority shareholders

Net interest income is the difference between the interest earned on assets, such as loans and investments, and the interest paid on liabilities, such as deposits and other borrowings. It is a measure of the profitability of a financial institution

Net non-operating interest income/expense is the difference between interest income and interest expense from non-operating activities, such as investments in other companies, real estate, or other non-operating assets or liabilities

Normalized ebitda (earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization) is a measure of a company's financial performance that excludes unusual or one-time expenses, such as restructuring costs or gains or losses from asset sales, to provide a more accurate picture of the company's ongoing operating performance

Normalized income is a company's earnings that have been adjusted to exclude unusual or one-time items that are not expected to recur in future periods. This measure provides a clearer view of the company's underlying profitability and performance
Operating expenses are the costs incurred by a company to carry out its normal business operations, such as salaries and wages, rent, utilities, and other general and administrative expenses

Operating income, also known as operating profit, is a company's earnings before interest and taxes (ebit). It represents the profit generated by a company's core business operations, excluding non-operating income and expenses
Operating revenue, also known as net sales or revenue from operations, is the amount of money a company generates from its normal business activities, excluding any non-operating income

Other g&a (general and administrative) expenses are expenses incurred by a company that are not directly related to its core business operations, such as legal and accounting fees, advertising, and office expenses

Other income and expense are gains or losses that are not directly related to a company's normal business operations. Examples include gains or losses from the sale of assets or investments, foreign exchange gains or losses, and interest income or expense from non-operating activities
Other operating expenses are expenses incurred by a company that are not directly related to its core business operations, such as research and development, advertising, and marketing expenses
Other special charges are unusual or one-time expenses that a company incurs, such as restructuring costs, asset write-downs, or legal settlements
Pretax income is a company's earnings before taxes are deducted. It is a measure of a company's profitability that excludes the impact of taxes
Pretax income is a company's earnings before taxes are deducted. It is a measure of a company's profitability that excludes the impact of taxes

Reconciled depreciation is the amount of depreciation expense that has been recognized on a company's financial statements, adjusted for any differences between the company's tax basis and book basis of its assets
Rent and landing fees are expenses incurred by companies in the airline industry, specifically related to the leasing of planes and payment for airport landing fees
Rent expense supplemental is additional information provided on a company's financial statements regarding its rental expenses, such as the amounts of rent paid for specific properties
Salaries and wages are expenses incurred by a company for employee compensation, including wages, salaries, bonuses, and benefits

Selling, general, and administrative (sg&a) expenses are the costs incurred by a company to support its sales and marketing efforts, including salaries and wages, advertising, travel and entertainment expenses, and other general and administrative expenses
Special income charges are unusual or one-time gains that a company realizes, such as gains from the sale of assets or investments or insurance recoveries
The amount of tax impact that is associated with any unusual item, including non-recurring and extraordinary items, that are included in the income statement
The amount of income tax liability that a company expects to pay in a given period. The tax provision is calculated by applying the applicable tax rate to the company's taxable income for the period

The effective tax rate used to calculate the tax provision for a given period. This rate is based on the company's statutory tax rate and any tax credits or deductions that are applicable in the given period

The effective tax rate used to calculate the tax provision for a given period. This rate is based on the company's statutory tax rate and any tax credits or deductions that are applicable in the given period
The sum of all costs incurred by a company during a specific period, including cost of goods sold, operating expenses, interest expenses, and taxes
The total income generated by a company's operating activities before any deductions or adjustments are made
The total cost of financing activities other than interest expenses, including fees for loan origination and servicing
The total amount of money generated by a company's sales and other activities during a specific period
The sum of all extraordinary and non-recurring items that are included in a company's income statement
The sum of all extraordinary and non-recurring items that are included in a company's income statement, excluding any items related to goodwill impairment
